filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of two copies—one uncolored and one hand colored—of Blake's engraved illustrations to Edward Young's Night Thoughts (1797). Both copies are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program).
With what must have been enormous energy, Blake executed 537 water colors illustrating the poem's nine sections, which Young called "Nights," for the publisher Richard Edwards. The 1797 volume included a selection of illustrations for the first four Nights, but Edwards closed his publishing business before any further volumes could be issued. Many copies include a two-page "Explanation of the Engravings," possibly written by Blake's friend and fellow-artist Henry Fuseli. The texts of these commentaries are included in the Editor's Notes for each plate.
The colorist(s) of the twenty-seven traced colored copies have never been convincingly identified. The copy now published in the Archive, from the Huntington Library, was very probably colored shortly after publication.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Library of Congress, the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.note: Blake probably began work on the *Night Thoughts* water-color designs in late 1794 or early 1795. The engravings bear imprints dated 1796 and 1797 and were published in 1797. The hand coloring was probably executed shortly after publication. This copy is designated as colored copy I in Bentley page 644.

desc.objtitle: Night the Firston Life, Death and Immortality., Object 1 (Bentley 515.1)

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Death, in the character of an old man, having swept away with one hand part of the family seen in this print, is presenting with the other their spirits to immortality."

illustration.illusobjdesc: Death, in the character of an old man, sits or crouches in the lower portion of the design. The figure is gowned and has long hair and a beard. Both feet are visible below the hem of his gown and his right foot may be raised on tiptoe. Death's right arm is down with the hand held down and the fingers spread. He may be touching the small figures to the right of his right hand. His left arm is not visible, but his left hand rests on his left knee with the palm turned up. An arrow with the tip pointing downward and the curved end of a bow are visible to the left of Death's right foot. The six figures below death likely represent a family. A female in a sleeveless gown sits in the lower portion of the design. She is likely the mother of the five nearby children. The figure faces forward with her head turned to the left; she may look down towards the nude, curly-haired child. The mother's right arm is bent upward and her left arm is down at her side. A distaff balances against her right arm and she holds a string or strand of thread with both hands. An open book with distinct pages rests on the female's right knee. Two children of indeterminate gender stand to the left of the seated female, facing right. Both are apparently gowned and have long hair. The child to the right holds a lyre, while the child to the left plays it. A nude child with curly hairpossibly malestands to the left of the seated female. He faces right in profile with his right leg bent back and his right foot raised on tiptoe. The right half of his body is cast in shadow. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees and extend up and to the right with the palms turned up. He holds a scroll with both hands and he may be reaching towards his mother to give her the scroll. A child of indeterminate gender stands to the left of the seated female. The figure is partially obscured by the figure to the left. The child has long hair and its head may be down; it may read the book resting on the mother's right knee. A gowned child with long hairpossibly malesits on the ground below the adult female. The child faces left in profile with his shoulders hunched slightly and his head down. He may be smiling. His left arm rests on his lap and he holds a tablet or sheet of paper in his left hand. His right arm rests on the tablet and he holds a quill pen in his right hand. Green wash below the figures of Death and the family may indicate grass. A shadow falls across the grass directly below the figures. A nude female spirit with long hair stands on the palm of Death's left hand. She is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer with her head bent back. The figure's buttocks are prominent. She stands with her legs together with both feet raised on tiptoe and her ankles touching. Both arms are raised vertically with the palms held vertically; she is probably reaching upwards. A gowned female with long hair flies or hovers in the upper right portion of the design; she may rise upward. The figure is transparent, as indicated by the horizontal lines of the sky running through her. She probably represents a soul or spirit. The figure faces left with her head turned up slightly. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees with the palms turned up. A pair of winged angels fly or hover in the upper portion of the design. The figure closest to the viewer is gowned and has long hair; the other figure is partially obscured so that only the head, left arm, and wing are clearly visible. Both figures may be female. The angels' bodies are horizontal with their heads to the right. Each figure extends a single arm to the right with the palm held out to the right. They may reach toward the transparent spirit to the right. The figure in back appears to be smiling. The upper portion of the sky is filled with clouds. Darkness or dark shadows appear in the sky to the left and right of Death.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A male with curly hair lies on his side in the lower portion of the design. The figure may be a shepherd. He faces forward with his torso twisted to the left. He wears a gown, shirt, or other clothing and is wrapped in a sheet or blanket. The figure's left arm is bent. His right arm is obscured by the sheet, but is likely bent up with the elbow resting on the ground and his hand supporting his head. He casts a shadow on the ground to the left. The figure's eyes are raised and his expression and posture may suggest melancholy. A vine with thirteen leaves grows to the left of the shepherd. The ground below the shepherd is covered with grass. A dog lies above the shepherd, facing right in profile. The dog's right eye is closed and it may be sleeping. A flock of perhaps twelve(?) sheep appear above and to the right of the shepherd. Two horned sheep face to the right with their heads down and eyes closed; they may be sleeping. The remaining sheep face away or to the left. A winged figure, possibly an angel or the personification of sleep, flies or hovers in the lower right portion of the design above the flock of sheep. He is nude and seen from behind with his buttocks prominent. The figure bends forward and to the right with his head down. Both arms extend downward. The palm of his left hand is held vertically and he holds a wand or rod in his right hand with the forefinger extended downward. A gowned figure lies in a prone position in the upper left portion of the design. The figure may wear a veil or other cloth drapery on his or her head. The figure's head is turned towards the viewer with the eyes closed; he or she may be sleeping. A band of clouds covers the left margin and the upper corners of the design. The night sky is dark and filled with as many as thirty-three stars.

His left foot is raised on tiptoe and he may walk to the left. The figure bends forward with his shoulders hunched slightly. Both arms are bent with the palms held vertically in front of his chest. His arms are raised horizontally with the palms turned down. His right foot is visible below and to the left of his left hand with the sole turned up. He is likely swimming. Clouds appear in the sky in the upper left and right portions of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curly haired male, probably representing the poet, lies on his side in the lower portion of the design. The figure is partly nude and is covered with a sheet or blanket. His head is turned up in profile with his mouth open and left eye raised. He looks up at Death with an expression of fear or surprise. Both arms are bent with the palms turned out towards the viewer and the fingers spread. His left elbow rests on a sheet or other fabric (perhaps covering a bed, with a pillow to the right) and likely supports the figure's weight. Death, in the character of an old man, crouches in the right portion of the design. He faces forward and has long hair and a beard. The figure's left leg is bent and drawn up with the knee and left foot prominent. His right leg extends down and to the left. Death's left arm is down at his side and he holds a bell in his left hand. His right arm is not pictured. An arrow and the curved end of a bow are visible to the left of Death, below the text panel. The bow casts a shadow to the right. Four objects rest on a table in the lower left portion of the design. The left portion of the table is cast in shadow. An hourglass stands furthest left; horizontal lines in the lower chamber suggest that it is filled with sand. To the right, a quill pen rests in an inkwell. A lit oil lamp rests on a rectangular block to the right. The lamp has a looped handle and may have a leaf or other vegetative design. The fire creates a small circle of light. An open book appears furthest right. The scene may take place in a room at night. A diagonal line appears on the wall above Death, with the area below cast in shadow.

He is seen from behind and stands with his legs spread apart; his right foot may be raised on tiptoe. His left arm is bent upward with the palm turned up slightly. Shadows in the lower portion of the design, particularly the lower right, may suggest clouds. The corpses of two male figures lie on a hill or mound in the lower portion of the design. They are probably kings. Both figures have slightly curly hair. Their heads are bent back and their eyes are closed. The figure to the right has a mustache and faces right. Only his head is clearly visible. A spiky crown rests on the ground to the right of the figure's head. The rounded objects above the crown may represent the hair of another figure. The figure to the left faces left with his head turned torwards the viewer. He wears a spiky crown and a gown, cloak, or robe with a circular brooch attached at the right shoulder. The figure's body likely extends horizontally to the right.

Time's right leg is bent and drawn up; his left leg is bent to the right with the left foot turned and resting on the instep. Both arms are down at his sides. His left palm is turned down with the thumb spread apart from the fingers, a gesture that suggests he is measuring time. His right palm is vertical and he holds the handle of a scythe in his right hand. Veins are clearly distinguishable on the figure's forearms, hands, left foot, and right calf. The figure casts a shadow below. The ground below Time may be covered with grass. A gowned female stands above the text panel. She faces forward with her torso bent to the left. Her left arm is bent and rests on top of an hourglass. The figure's head is down and rests on her arm. Her eyes are closed and she may be sleeping. The figure's long hair falls over the left edge of the hourglass. Her right leg is bent and crossed in front of her left with the right foot raised on tiptoe. Horizontal hatching lines in the upper chamber of the hourglass indicate sand, with some grains descending in a straight line in the lower chamber. The sky is filled with clouds.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "Two figures, intended to represent Sense and Reason, pointing to another scene of things, and admonishing the author that it is time for him to depart from the present."

Eve is seen from behind with her head turned to the right; she looks towards the crouched figure to the right. Eve stands with her legs spread apart and her right foot raised on tiptoe. Her left hand is raised at 135 degrees with the palm turned upward. Her right arm is raised at 45 degrees and she points downward with her right forefinger extended. Adam's right arm is raised at 135 degrees with the palm turned up. His left arm is obscured by the text panel; his left hand appears below the text panel, pointing downward. A male with short, curly hair crouches in the lower right portion of the design. He may represent the poet. The figure faces right with his head turned to the left; he looks toward Adam and Eve. Both arms are bent to the right. His hands are held together as if in prayer with the fingers interlaced. A large structure, probably a tomb built of stone, appears in the left portion of the design. A Gothic arch forms the entryway; Adam's right foot rests on the sill below the darkened doorway. The upper portion of the arch is decorated with a leaf or other vegetative motif. The statue, wall painting, or sculpted relief of a gowned, winged angel appears above the arch, to the left. The angel faces right with its right arm raised at 135 degrees. The right palm is turned up and the angel holds an object, perhaps a wreath or crown of laurel leaves, above the apex of the arch. The decoration on the entry at the top is flame-like. The left arm and head of a second figure are visible to the right; the figure is partially obscured by the text panel. The ground below the figures is covered with grass. Blue wash to the right of the tomb indicates sky. White space in the lower right corner may suggest a cloud.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A female with long hair and a spiky crown sits in the left portion of the design; the figure represents the personification of Reason. She faces forward with her eyes cast down; she looks at the figure below. The figure wears a gown with a belt or other tie at the waist. The collar of the gown is spiky, and may represent a necklace. Reason's right knee and foot are prominent. Her right arm is raised vertically. The fingers on her right hand are spread and she holds a pair of balances above her head. A female representing the personification of Faith appears in the lower portion of the design. The figure is partly nude and wears a skirt or other drapery. She is seen from behind with her head bent back and turned up. Her hair is long and partially drawn back in a bun. The figure sits on a step with her right leg bent and left leg extended to the right. Both feet are visible and she wears sandals. Her right foot is raised on tiptoe. Her left arm is braced with her hand on the ground and the palm turned down. Her right arm is bent and extends to the right. The figure holds a quill pen in her right hand; she writes on a piece of paper or tablet resting on her left knee. Her right hand and the pen cast shadows on the paper or tablet. A stone tablet or other rectangular object appears below and to the right of the text panel. Two stairs or steps extend across the lower portion of the design. Faith rests on the lower step, while Reason sits above. Two vertical lines hint at a post (possibly part of a doorway) far right. Horizontal lines and blue wash in the upper portion of the design indicates sky. The white area to the right of the text panel suggests clouds.

objnote.p: The description of this design in the "Explanation of the Engravings" is as follows: "A personification of Truth, as she is represented by the poet, bursting on the last moments of the sinner ‘in thunder and in flame.’"

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude female crouches to the right of the text panel. The figure represents the personification of Truth. She faces forward with her breasts exposed. The figure's long, curly hair stands partially on end and appears flame-like. The locks on either side of her head suggest spirals. The figure's left leg is bent and drawn up; her left foot rests on a stone and is raised on tiptoe. Her right leg extends down and to the left. Both arms are raised vertically and she points upward with a finger on each hand. The figure's mouth is open with the teeth visible. Her expression suggests anger. The scene may take place in a cave. Dark shadows appear on the (stony?) walls above and to the left and right of the figure. A single bolt of lightning appears along the right border of the design and extends below Truth. Fire rises from the lower left corner of the design and extends above the figure; the dark shadow above may represent smoke.
